body.p:
Thursday Morning
Papa says my dear Friend that he half promised if the weather was open to drive over today to course--as the weather is you could not expect him, & I write chiefly to congratulate you all on the consoling opinion of Mr. Lawrence, & to enquire after my dear Eliza whose cough quite frightened Papa & whose threat of going out yesterday fairly put him
(I think my blotting paper is frozen) fairly put him in a passion. Write on Saturday & tell me how she is.--Will you tell your dear Father with my love that we have determined to send my little Stratford Bitch to Mr. Haydon & I shall not therefore trouble him for a greyhound--His seem all so good that it would be a pity to send them to a painter's room & mine being untried & very pretty will suit our Artist
without exciting so much regret in parting with her.

Mama will not I am afraid come home till Wednesday or Thursday--she is quite well but very homesick.--Did Papa tell you & Miss Jeremy how pretty Molly looks now she is washed--as white as swansdown & as glossy as floss silk--I wish you would come & see her.--Is Mr. Bailey with Mr. Dobbs? Don't forget to tell me.--Love to the dear Papa--the dear Eliza--the dear
Aunt Mary--the dear Miss Jeremy.--the dear Kate Wheeler--& last not least the dear Mary Webb.-- Ever your's M.R.M.

I had a letter yesterday from Miss James full of kind messages to you all. Poor Miss Ramsay (with whom Miss Emily went to Lisbon) is dead--the third sister who has gone off just as they were opening into Womanhood.--Sister Susan quite Well & comfortable & talking of coming to Town in the Spring.
